Description: Oil-jar (alabastron); ledge below the rim, narrow neck, elongated body and rounded base; calcite; fine-walled and well polished; faint trace of lathe point in the centre of the base on the underside.
Curator's comments: The shape resembles the alabastron used for holding oil, especially perfumed oil. Alabastra were first attested in ancient Egypt (from the 11th century BC) and were originally carved from alabaster. The tradition spread via ancient Greece to other parts of the classical world and were produced in pottery, glass and metal. A fragment excavated at Heid ibn Aqil may be from a similar vessel and can be dated to before the middle of the first century AD (Cleveland 1965, pp. 102, TC 904).
Acquisition name: Donated by: D B Doe, MBE
